sajid khan wrote:
> Hi,
> First I want to thank Mr.Gordon Mohr for the instant reply.
> I tried DecideRuleScope with following filters:
>         1) Accept all urls
>         2) URIRegExpFilter - if urls match the filter, eliminate them.
> This is the regular expression:
>    .*(?i)(\\.(jpg|jpeg|gif|tiff|svg|pdf))$
>                                                                                                                              
> 
> It still picks files ending in gif, jpeg...etc.

Once you're using a DecidingScope, no "filter" classes would usually 
come into play. Instead you'd use a MatchesRegExpDecideRule, or for your 
purposes perhaps even MatchesFilePatternDecideRule, which includes 
pre-designed patterns for non-HTML file suffixes.

So rules that should work would be:

(1) RejectDecideRule
(2) MatchesRegExpDecideRule with the right regex *and* a configured 
REJECT decision

...and no other later rules that might overrule the REJECT with an ACCEPT.

> I also tried domainScope with an exclude filter. It contained only a 
> URIRegExpFilter which returns true if the regular expression is 
> matched.  But still it is not working.

This should also work if configured properly, though I (and others) 
often have a hard time remembering whether a filter should be returning 
'true' or 'false' to have the desired accept/reject effect in different 
contexts -- which is a reason why the more explicit DecideRule approach 
is now preferred.

- Gordon @ IA


>         The urls of the gif/pdf files, which get picked, match the 
> regular expression (tested using a simple java program).
> That means the regular expression is fine.
> 
> I'm not sure where I'm going wrong here.
> 
> Regards,
> Sajid
> 
> 
> 
> On 1/20/07, *Gordon Mohr * <gojomo@... 
> <mailto:gojomo@...>> wrote:
> 
>     sajid khan wrote:
>     >  Hi,
>     >  I dont want to save images and pdf files while crawling under the
>     >  domainScope.
>     >  So, I enabled the additionalScopeFocus filter and set it to return
>     false
>     >  when the below reg exp is satisfied:
>      >
>     .*(?i)(*\\.(jpg|jpeg|gif|tiff|svg|pdf))$*<file://%5C%5C.%28jpg%7Cjpeg%7Cgif%7Ctiff%7Csvg%7Cpdf%29%29$/>
> 
>     >
>     >
>     >  In spite of this, gif and jpegs get picked up. I can see that they're
>     >  consuming a couple of MBs when I look at the crawl report.
>     >  Can anybody please give pointers on how to fix it or where I may
>     be going
>     >  wrong?
> 
>     In the classic scopes, the additionalScopeFocus filter can rule things
>     in with a 'true' response, but not rule things out. A 'false' just
>     means
>     'this isn't something to be extra-added' -- if the URL still is
>     accepted
>     by the general scope, it's still in.
> 
>     That's why in the newer, recommended, and usually more efficient
>     DecideRule approach, every rule has both a test *and* a decision to
>     apply. A proper sequence of rules can accomplish almost every effect
>     imaginable.
> 
>     In the classic scopes, to rule things out, set up excludeFilters.
> 
>     If translating the classic approach to the chain-of-decide-rules
>     approach, the rules would roughly be...
> 
>     (1) Set initial decision to reject
>     (2) If seed, set decision to accept.
>     (3) If in 'focus' (domains in the case of DomainScope), set decision to
>     accept.
>     (4) If 'additional focus' filter applies, set decision to accept.
>     (5) If transitively included by referring hops, set decision to accept.
>     (6) If 'excluded' filter applies, set decision to reject.
> 
>     ...with the last decision applied winning.
> 
>     - Gordon @ IA
> 
> 
>
